coredata.dc:title: Influence of the potential on the dielectric constant of inert gases
coredata.dc:creator: Vermesse, J.
Levesque, D.
Weis, J.J.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Dielectric constants of Ar, Kr and Xe at room temperature are calculated by molecular dynamics in the constant-polarizability approximation for three potentials: the Lennard-Jones, the multiparameter pair potential of Barker et al., and the multiparameter potential with an Axilrod—Teller three-body potential. The three-body potential has negligible effect but differences are found between the Lennard-Jones and multiparameter potentials.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 80, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 1 June 1981 INFLUENCE OF THE POTENTIAL ON THE DIELECTRIC CONSTANT OF INERT GASES J. VERMESSE Laboratoire des Interactions Moleculaires et des Hautes Pressions. CNRS. Centre Universitaire de Paris-Nord, 93430 Villetaneuse, France and D. LEVESQUE and JJ. WEIS Laboratoire de Physique Theorique et Hautes Energies*, Unwersitede Pans-Sud, 91405 Orsay Cedex, France Received 7 February 1981; in final form 23 February 1981 Dielectric constants of Ar, Kr and Xe at room temperature are calculated by molecular dynamics in the constant-polar- izability approximation for three potentials: the Lennard-Jones, the multiparameter pair potential of Barker et al., and the multiparameter potential with an Axilrod—Teller three-body potential. The three-body potential has negligible effect but differences are found between the Lennard-Jones and multiparameter potentials. It is now well known that effective pair potentials such as the widely used Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential fail to give an accurate description of the inert gases. A better description can be obtained by using a pan- potential appropriate to the gas phase together with an Axilrod—Teller three-body potential [1 ]. Only a few dense-gas or liquid-state properties have been re- ported for this class of potential [2—6] (mainly be- cause simulations involving three-body forces consume a relatively large amount of computer time). Exam- ples are calculations of the equation of state of argon [2], krypton [4] and xenon [4], the viscosity of xenon [4] and the structure factor of krypton [5,6]. They generally are in good agreement with experiment. In this paper we investigate the influence of the in- teraction potential on the dielectric constant ofAr.Kr and Xe at room temperature. A full calculation of the dielectric constant is, however, not intended. Besides the interaction potential it requires knowledge of the two-body polarizability and possibly also of higher-or- der polarizabilities [7,8]. Since no precise information (t Laboratoire associe au Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique. on these quantities is available for the heavier inert gases we adopt a constant-polarizability model (DID limit). Although it fails to reproduce experiment [9], it is still of help for estimating the influence of the in- teraction potential. In the constant-polarizability approximation, the Clausius—Mossotti relation can be written [9] e-1 3 (1) e+2 4irpOQ with A=io^ Z) Z? «r^r^>-<r^x'r^». (2) /^i k^f In eq. (2) the dipole—dipole tensor is defined by Tf-ri,3^^.^,). (3) p is the number of particles per unit volume and OQ the isolated-atom polarizability. As the dielectric constant will be calculated for an isotropic sample and periodic boundary conditions, the last term in (2) vanishes and hence 0 009-2614/81/0000-OOOO/S 02.50 © North-Holland Publishing Company 283 Volume 80, number 2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS I June 1981 A^a^2--//-^ (4) (5) (6) (7) with R^ =Sf +Sf. S ^:-.6 "3 "'m <T- "V In these expressions ^(r) denotes the pair distribution function and r^ the distance at which the'pair poten- tial is a minimum- (Note that these defmitions ofS^ and S^2 differ from those ofrefs. [8,9] by a factor (o/r )6 where a is the distance at which the pair poten- tial is zero.) A is evaluated by molecular dynamics for three types of potential: the Lennard-Jones (12.6) (LJ) po- tential, the multiparameter pair potential (MP) of Barker and co-workers, and the MP potential together with the Axilrod—Teller three-body potential (MP + DDD); DDD = v(l + 3 cos 0 ^ cos @2 cos 0^){r3 r^r^. (8) Oi,6-i,Qi are the angles of the triangle formed by the particles i,j, /.The parameters characterizing these po- tentials are summarized in table 1. The numbers of particles used in the molecular dynamics simulations are 108 for the U and MP potentials, 64 when the triple-dipole potential is added All potentials and the sums mR^2 have been truncated at a distance r^ of the order of 2.5 r^. To correct for this truncation a long-range contribution assuming g(r) = 1 has been added to the pair term Sj2. The total Rzz = 5j2 + 5j2 is rather insensitive to the truncation [8] and no cor- rection term has been added. Results for A along the 298 K isotherm are given in table 2. It is first noted that the influence of the triple-di- pole potential on the deviation from the Clausius— Mossotti expression is small. For the densities pr^ = 0.4 (Xe) and 0.6 (Kr) both the MP potential and the MP + DDD potential give identical results within sta- tistical error. For the higher density pr^. = 0.8 (Xe) a difference of 5% is observed, but some of this differ- ence may be due to the use of a rather small cut-off distance in the evaluation ofR22 when the three-body potential is included. On the other hand, the use of either a LJ or a MP potential produces a non-negligible effect on A. For argon the difference amounts to 10%. Tlus is also the order of magnitude observed for light scattering intensities at low density [13]. For the heavy inert gas Xe the effect of the potential change appears to be as large as 30%. In view of these results it seems essential to use pre- cise potential forms when analyzing dielectric or light- scattering data in order to extract accurate informa- tion on the polarizability tensor [14]. In this context it would be useful [14] to do a molecular dynamics calculation for the light scattering intensity of argon near the triple point using a MP potential (from what is found here for the dielectric constant the contribu- tion of the triple-dipole interaction would probably have a negligible effect). We are presently carrying out such a calculation. A23 (1981) 77. 285 ng-range contribution assuming g(r) = 1 has been added to the pair term Sj2. The total Rzz = 5j2 + 5j2 is rather insensitive to the truncation [8] and no cor- rection term has been added. Results for A along the 298 K isotherm are given in table 2. It is first noted that the influence of the triple-di- pole potential on the deviation from the Clausius— Mossotti expression is small. For the densities pr^ = 0.4 (Xe) and 0.6 (Kr) both the MP potential and the MP + DDD potential give identical results within sta- tistical error. For the higher density pr^. = 0.8 (Xe) a difference of 5% is observed, but some of this differ- ence may be due to the use of a rather small cut-off distance in the evaluation ofR22 when the three-body potential is included. On the other hand, the use of either a LJ or a MP potential produces a non-negligible effect on A. For argon the difference amounts to 10%. Tlus is also the order of magnitude observed for light scattering intensities at low density [13]. For the heavy inert gas Xe the effect of the potential change appears to be as large as 30%. In view of these results it seems essential to use pre- cise potential forms when analyzing dielectric or light- scattering data in order to extract accurate informa- tion on the polarizability tensor [14]. In this context it would be useful [14] to do a molecular dynamics calculation for the light scattering intensity of argon near the triple point using a MP potential (from what is found here for the dielectric constant the contribu- tion of the triple-dipole interaction would probably have a negligible effect). We are presently carrying out such a calculation. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Dielectric constants of Ar, Kr and Xe at room temperature are calculated by molecular dynamics in the constant-polarizability approximation for three potentials: the Lennard-Jones, the multiparameter pair potential of Barker et al., and the multiparameter potential with an Axilrod—Teller three-body potential. The three-body potential has negligible effect but differences are found between the Lennard-Jones and multiparameter potentials.
